nature.translation[0].definitions[0].def: everything in the physical world that is not controlled by humans, such as wild plants and animals, earth and rocks, and the weather
nature.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: We grew up in the countryside, surrounded by the beauties of nature.
Disease is nature’s way of keeping the population down.
The inhabitants of the island fight a constant battle against the forces of nature.
All these materials are found in nature.
nature.translation[0].definitions[0].not: ‘the nature’ in this meaning You say
nature.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: a child with a happy, easy-going nature
I tried appealing to his better nature (=his feelings of kindness) but he wouldn’t agree to help us.
Of course she’s jealous – it’s only human nature (=the feelings and ways of behaving that all people have).
It’s just not in Jane’s nature to lie.
She was by nature a very affectionate person.
nature.translation[0].definitions[2].def: the qualities or features that something has
nature.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Capitalist society is by its very nature unstable.
The exact nature of the problem is not well understood.
Any government funding would be temporary in nature.
They asked a lot of questions about the nature of our democracy.
He examined the nature of the relationship between the two communities.
nature.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: The support being given is of a practical nature.
I never trouble myself with questions of that nature.
nature.translation[1].definitions[0].def: a British weekly journal (=serious magazine) which deals with all areas of science. It is a very respected journal, and many important new discoveries are first reported in articles in Nature.
